Then the Matcha comes though to hit the (F5) on the keyboard to refresh you like Sprite Remix Aruba Jam (BTW if anyone can get me an unopened can or 12pack of this I will give you a bunch of ShhhMoneys it's Dreams Money Can Buy for me or I will settle for Banana Snapple)!!!

Horchata- Boba guys should be bangin and flexin Tacos in this Trap House cause this Horchata is Bangs more than those Bros Bangin Tacos In those buses. If ChauTime were to give this flavor a nickname I would name it this alright.... just hear me out ok, gimme a chance will ya, I know I'm not the best nicknamer ever but I'd call it Bang Bros cause it Slays Trick while eliminating the rest of the competition. Beyonce Formation Tour Coming Soon!!! 

Hong Kong Milk Tea- Just like all the desserts or any sweets I have tried that are Hong Kong or Hong Kong Style this was just mediocre. I don't know if people in Hong Kong don't have taste buds or anything but everything I have ever tried Hong Kong Style are Bland A.F. with no sugar and no flavor. One thing that I remember most is two weeks into February... wait I mean April but same feelings, on my birthday as a kid I use to look forward to the Hong Kong Piece Of Cake my Grandma Bling use to get me. Phuckin Luved Dat Sh*t. Now a days that is just A Waste Of Stomach Space so I guess for this Flavor Boba Guys Nails it and it lives up to its name Hong Kong Milk Tea.

Thai Ice Tea- Thai Down Pho What. Did this flavor put me in a world where I am riding on a 6'7 Baby Elephant with 24k  elephant tusks with diamond encrusted Tiffany & Co. 24k VS1  deep fried elephant ears while sippin On 2 Moscow Mule cups filled with Thai Ice Tea with a tin tray of Khao Soi and 2Chopsticks right by my side?!! No but it was different and better executed than the average over sugary and half and half basic drinks at Thai Restaurants.  

Wish I could have any of those in the palms of my hands right now it's the one of my many secrets formulas to staying "Slim Thick With My Cute Ass" oh yeah P.S. ChauTime Booty By Chau Videos coming soon just subscribe and get that work out so you can Twerk N Phuck Up Your New Louboutins N Jimmy Choos. 

Line can be crazy at times so get in "Formation" while bumpin Beyonce with your most Vogue Skimpy Outfit on and get ready to Work Work Work Work Work and Slay All Day, Okay, Slay!!!

-Damn ChauTime Back At It Again!!!

excerpts: I settled on the Hong Kong style milk tea with boba.
Tasty.
Fresh.
Sweet.
Everything you could want in a good milk tea.
The service is good, and the atomsphere is super hip.
The wait in line is always more bearable with good music in the background!
Anyways, I had a little taste of the beverages that my friends got, and everything seems delicious.
hong kong style.author: Stefanie C.
hong kong style.review:
I'm excited that a Boba Guys location opened up closer to where I live. The other one is too far away! Or maybe I'm just spoiled. Anyways, I cannot resist a pit stop for boba when I'm taking a walk in the area. The line gets long pretty fast, but it's a small place so most people just grab and go so it's not too crowded. Plus there are a ton of unique menu items so you will have plenty of time to decide what you really want.

I settled on the Hong Kong style milk tea with boba. Tasty. Fresh. Sweet. Everything you could want in a good milk tea. The service is good, and the atomsphere is super hip. The wait in line is always more bearable with good music in the background! Anyways, I had a little taste of the beverages that my friends got, and everything seems delicious. My boyfriend got the coffee milk tea with boba... the boba ended up tasting like coffee. That was awesome.

I still cannot figure out the Boba Guys animal mascot... how peculiar.

excerpts: The Hong Kong Style Milk Tea with boba was better, but way too sweet!
If possible, ask for less condensed milk.
hong kong style.author: Christine S.
hong kong style.review:
You would think a shop called Boba Guys would get their balls right. Unfortunately, every mouthful was a surprise. Some were perfectly QQ (no, I'm not a fob) and some were way overcooked. Yikes!

Horchata with boba is probably the most *unique* drink here, because really, have you seen any other boba places with horchata? The drink itself was not bad, but it's not something I'd get again. It's definitely a "been there, done that" sort of thing. The Hong Kong Style Milk Tea with boba was better, but way too sweet! If possible, ask for less condensed milk.

excerpts: Next time I would like to try their Hong Kong style milk tea and see how it is!
hong kong style.author: Simon C.
hong kong style.review:
I just moved from Fremont to San Francisco few weeks ago - one of the things I truly miss is the different boba tea houses - tea island, gong cha, T4, tea papa... You name it. And I live far away from sunset so I can't really go purple kow that often; luckily, I found this little gem in the Mission district.

Boba guys - the name doesn't sound really serious and at first I would thought it's another "me too" boba tea houses. But no! Just by reading their menu you can understand the owner has put a lot of thoughts on their drinks. Not only the detailed explanation of each of their signature drinks; you can also find a lot of little notes on the counter, wall etc about their vision, philosophy and origins. You can learn a lot about this place just by reading those signs.

So basically there are two big categories on their menu: specialty or signature drinks, and slow drip tea. For the latter category, you can choose sweetness and whether you want to add milk in it (and they have organic milk, California farm milk or soy milk as well). First time here, let me try their slow drip tea and see if they have done the fundamentals right.



-) Muscat Oolong Milk Tea with boba: A. They brewed the tea fresh from your order, turn the teapot/funnel thing upside down, and literally let the tea drip slowly. After it's done, they would pour it into a prepared beaker with iced milk, and there you go your drink. When I first sipped it, it definitely had a very strong oolong tea flavor in it. I really like the fact that the milk was not creamy at all; rather, the milk helped bring out the taste of the tea, make it more smooth, and definitely enhanced the overall experience. Boba was definitely way above average. Soft and chewy, but it's not honey boba so it's not sweet at all, which actually makes sense or else it would not go well with the strong flavor tea.

Definitely a place that I will be visiting more often. Next time I would like to try their Hong Kong style milk tea and see how it is!

excerpts: The Hong Kong style milk tea tasted authentic
so I was very pleased because I usually only trust asian cafes with my HK style milk tea.
I'll need to come back here and try the horchata milk tea...
Drinks come in 2 sizes:
16oz or 12oz for cold, and only 16oz for hot.
It's $3.50 for a 16oz and 50cents for toppings (boba, pudding, almond jelly).
Service is fast and they're very friendly!
hong kong style.author: Bianca M.
hong kong style.review:
I remember when this place was a popup shop in a ramen shop and they also served curry! Now it's just boba.
The shop is cute and the boba is perfect and the drinks are delicious. The Hong Kong style milk tea tasted authentic so I was very pleased because I usually only trust asian cafes with my HK style milk tea. I'll need to come back here and try the horchata milk tea...
Drinks come in 2 sizes: 16oz or 12oz for cold, and only 16oz for hot. It's $3.50 for a 16oz and 50cents for toppings (boba, pudding, almond jelly).
Service is fast and they're very friendly! Awesome customer service

They also sell other things like special mason jars, tin cups, buttons, shirts, tea leaves, and flavoured cotton candy. My only complaint would be the price of their cute mason jar. $12?! I understand it has their logo and a special lid with room for a straw but the it only saves you 25cents when you bring it in. And initially you have to pay $12 + the drink you want which averages $16 total.. That a bit intense for a 16oz mason jar of milk tea. And since you only save 25cents when you bring it in again, you'll need to come here at least 48 to make it worth it... The jar is SO cute, I just don't think it's worth $12.
BESIDES THE JAR, the milk tea at Boba Guys is amazing and I think they've really nailed the science behind preparing good boba and drinks. Awesome job, I just wish I was in the area more often to enjoy it.

excerpts: Their hong kong style milk tea that has CONDENSED MILK IN IT!?
IDK YO.
Seriously it was really great.
I do have to say that I'm appreciative that despite the high amount of traffic that they receive, they churn out drinks in a pretty consistent basis.
Although, I'm sure that's not always the case, but for my case it was seriously on point.
In and out within 30 minutes!
hong kong style.author: Alan D.
hong kong style.review:
Yeah, I'll roll out the red carpet you jerks.

This was stupid good. I'm talking about so good it's just stupid. A friend of mine suggested we go here for milk tea, and sure why not? I'll never pass up the opportunity to try a new boba place.

Yo... what the fuck? That was amazing. Their hong kong style milk tea that has CONDENSED MILK IN IT!? IDK YO. Seriously it was really great. I do have to say that I'm appreciative that despite the high amount of traffic that they receive, they churn out drinks in a pretty consistent basis. Although, I'm sure that's not always the case, but for my case it was seriously on point. In and out within 30 minutes!

excerpts: Hong Kong style w/ condensed milk
is MY current Boba Guys favorite.
Strong black tea expertly brewed and just the right amount of condensed milk added?
Easy Sunday.
hong kong style.author: Susy C.
hong kong style.review:
I can always count on Boba Guys for excellent tea, this has never changed. 

Hong Kong style w/ condensed milk is MY current Boba Guys favorite. Strong black tea expertly brewed and just the right amount of condensed milk added? Easy Sunday. Then to top it off, perfectly cooked boba balls? 

The last time definitely had to have been a fluke. 

Really love how Boba Guys has expanded. They make their own jellies (almond & grass!) , macarons, and Kaya bread. They also carry Sugar & Spun (cotton candy). 

Also!!! They have handled mason jars with the logo for sale, $10. It's my personal favorite and I use mine daily at home. 

Oh and if you have the time and enjoy a great cup of tea, give the slow bar a shot. 

Keep up the good work guys!!

excerpts: But they had a lot of other drinks on the menu that made me want to try something different - they offer an horchata boba (that's very original), an iced matcha latte, Hong Kong style boba (black tea with condensed milk), and a Thai tea boba (I love Thai iced tea).
I'd like to try the matcha latte and the Thai tea the next time I visit!
hong kong style.author: Sylvia K.
hong kong style.review:
Am I in a science laboratory or in a boba shop?? It's a mix of the two and I love it! There are all kinds of glass beakers and glass test tubes that hold tea leaves and tools like matcha whisks and such. Such a creative idea on styling the space. There was even like a glass beaker terrarium on the counter. They have a statement on their outside window by the door about how they put a lot if science into their boba making process, which is pretty clever. The only thing that would make this even more awesome is if the employees wore white lab coats and safety glasses while making the boba. But I guess that would be really hot - it was already a warm day in the Mission when I visited and it gets pretty warm inside this little shop, especially with lots of people inside. They also had some fans on, so maybe there's no central AC. So...maybe no lab coats...

They also sell cute mason jars with their logo (I think it's an aardvark? They like boba too!) for $10. Not only is it cute, but it's reusable! If you bring the glass mason jar in, you get 25 cents off your order. So you're helping the environment by reducing waste and saving some money too! Technically, you'll need to visit 40 times to break even, but if you are planning to go everyday, or even like every week for a year, it will pay for itself. Plus you can use it for other beverages at home too. It has a handle. 

Ok, so how about the most important thing - the boba? I ordered the classic milk tea with tapioca balls - it was my visit and I needed to go with something basic. But they had a lot of other drinks on the menu that made me want to try something different - they offer an horchata boba (that's very original), an iced matcha latte, Hong Kong style boba (black tea with condensed milk), and a Thai tea boba (I love Thai iced tea). 

The milk tea was really good - just the perfect sweetness. Very refreshing on such a warm day. Maybe it tasted good because they use local Straus milk, I don't know. The tapioca was just a tad chewier than I prefer. But the liquid part was yummy. I'm not a boba connoisseur but I know what I like when I taste it. Even though it was busy, my order came out in like five minutes from the time that I ordered it. Speedy! 

I'd like to try the matcha latte and the Thai tea the next time I visit!

excerpts: #2: hong kong style
milk tea w/
almond jelly & boba (75% sweetness) - my current fav!
The milk tea is tasty, with a good tea and milk ratio.
But the star of the drink is the ALMOND JELLY!
I highly recommend that with any milk tea (not sure how it tastes with other drinks).
hong kong style.author: Christine N.
hong kong style.review:
Just when I thought my SF boba adventures couldn't get any better, 

I have heard about this place for a while and finally got to check it out. And from the # of check ins, you can tell I came back for more! Who knew an antelope would be an iconic mascot for a boba drink.

Drinks:

#1: horchata - It was delicious! The cinnamon flavor was prominent but not too overpowering. Don't expect it to be like the kind you would get from a taqueria but it comes pretty close. 

#2: hong kong style milk tea w/ almond jelly & boba (75% sweetness) - my current fav! The milk tea is tasty, with a good tea and milk ratio. But the star of the drink is the ALMOND JELLY! I highly recommend that with any milk tea (not sure how it tastes with other drinks). The boba has a good chewy texture too. 

#3: mango matcha latte w/boba - The cool colors of the drink caught my eye. okay taste. But not great enough to get a second time. 

Everything else:

The drinks come out pretty fast and the employees are patient and helpful with deciding on drink orders. The place is small with no more than 4 seats so expect a grab for the go type of situation.

excerpts:
Here are the drinks I've tried:
Hong Kong style tea with condensed milk:
VERY sweet, even when we ordered less sweet.
I've also tried it with half sweet, and in this case the coffee like flavour of the hong kong style tea showed through more.
Either way, their hong kong style tea is pretty good.
hong kong style.author: Theresa L.
hong kong style.review:
I've come here multiple times and have experienced both the long line and no line at all - it really depends on what time you arrive. 

Here are the drinks I've tried:
Hong Kong style tea with condensed milk: VERY sweet, even when we ordered less sweet. I've also tried it with half sweet, and in this case the coffee like flavour of the hong kong style tea showed through more. Either way, their hong kong style tea is pretty good.
Jasmine milk tea: Standard jasmine milk tea, refreshing and well made.
Iced Matcha latte: Perfect balance of matcha flavour without making it too bitter. 

Their boba is quite nice and chewy too with a good consistency. They also sell boba guys mason jars which look pretty cute if you want to fit into the hipster mission district. I think my only complaint is that it's quite expensive when it comes to milk tea places and it's just on par with other places such as sharetea/chatime/kung fu tea.

excerpts: Boba Guys sells two types of Toast, Kaya and Hong Kong Style.
The former, home-made coconut jam and honey.
The latter a whipped sweet cream also with honey.
hong kong style.author: James G.
hong kong style.review:
Boba Guys sells two types of Toast, Kaya and Hong Kong Style. The former, home-made coconut jam and honey. The latter a whipped sweet cream also with honey. Both are on top of lightly toasted brioche.

Today, uncharacteristically, the Kaya was not sold out.

Four Stars.

excerpts: For desserts, there are Hong Kong style French toast and Kaya toast from Malaysia/Singapore.
hong kong style.author: Charles S.
hong kong style.review:
High quality tea and milk.  There are numbers of selection from Thai Tea, black tea, oolong, and even Indian Chai (rare at tapioca tea place).  Milk includes regular milk, almond milk, and soy milk.  Toppings include tapioca, almond jelly, and grass jelly.  For desserts, there are Hong Kong style French toast and Kaya toast from Malaysia/Singapore.  Also, you can buy tea leaf by pounds.

I drink Chai without sugar the most and taste is authentic.

excerpts: Went with a few friends last week and we ordered four separate drinks, including the iced matcha latte with boba, Hong Kong style, and hojicha.
The Iced Matcha Latte drink is also highly recommended, while the Hong Kong style was good but not quite anything special.
The Iced Matcha Latte drink is also highly recommended, while the Hong Kong style was good but not quite anything special.
hong kong style.author: Matthew L.
hong kong style.review:
Had never bothered going to this place, but had definitely heard the hype. 

Went with a few friends last week and we ordered four separate drinks, including the iced matcha latte with boba, Hong Kong style, and hojicha. Personally, I ordered the Hojicha at 0% sugar, while I also got a taste of the other drinks. 

Through my experience, I concluded one thing - AMAZING tea flavors! I highly recommend that if you go to Boba Guys, order one of their premium milk teas, and order it with a lower sugar content level. Many milk tea places mask the poor quality of their actual teas with sweetening agents, and if you actually try their teas with low sweetness levels, it becomes alarmingly similar to just drinking milk and no tea. However, my Hojicha was very flavorful by itself, and it complemented nicely with the general sweetness of the boba toppings. 

The Iced Matcha Latte drink is also highly recommended, while the Hong Kong style was good but not quite anything special.

excerpts: Hong Kong style milk tea!
The tea is pretty good, but if you take your time, the boba balls gets all hard and not yummy
hong kong style.author: Christina T.
hong kong style.review:
Hong Kong style milk tea! 
The tea is pretty good, but if you take your time, the boba balls gets all hard and not yummy

excerpts: Tried a Hong Kong style milk tea and their signature horchata.
Maybe because I know Mexican horchata
I'm disappointed
but it wasn't sweet or creamy enough.
The milk tea was good, I'd order it again
but I definitely will not stand in a 20 minute line for the Boba guys ever again.
In a nutshell- overrated.
hong kong style.author: Ashlee L.
hong kong style.review: To call your self "Boba guys" should imply your Boba simply can't be beat. I wish I loved it but it was just good Boba, not great. Tried a Hong Kong style milk tea and their signature horchata. Maybe because I know Mexican horchata I'm disappointed but it wasn't sweet or creamy enough. The milk tea was good, I'd order it again but I definitely will not stand in a 20 minute line for the Boba guys ever again. In a nutshell- overrated.

excerpts: a hot Hong Kong style milk tea was perfect for a breezy sf night.

I did the most for my photo to post on yelp that I accidentally dropped a full cup of boba & they were nice enough to clean it up for me & replace it for free  5/5 for overall the freshness of the tea & great customer service, will definitely be back!
hong kong style.author: Moriah D.
hong kong style.review: First time here & parking is an ass, I really wish parking in sf wasn't this horrible! Esp getting something quick & easy like a drink. But regardless, so glad I came! A few friends really wanted to try this place out so my bf & I tagged along. I got a coconut green milk tea (4/5) I tried my friends drinks & honestly thought their drinks tasted better, definitely coming back for my own full cup! the Muscat oolong milk tea was really good & a hot Hong Kong style milk tea was perfect for a breezy sf night. I did the most for my photo to post on yelp that I accidentally dropped a full cup of boba & they were nice enough to clean it up for me & replace it for free  5/5 for overall the freshness of the tea & great customer service, will definitely be back!

excerpts:
Coffee Milk Tea: $4
Hong Kong Style:  ($4) Black tea with organic condensed milk

Bonus points for having both soy milk and almond milk options!
hong kong style.author: Kitty K.
hong kong style.review:
Tiny shop on Valencia and 19th, there's a few stools inside but it's almost always packed here. Since they're located in the Mission, parking is going to be fairly difficult to find too.

I love how they portray the process of making boba like a science (since I'm a bit of a nerd). They still have the lab coats behind the front door on the wall, and they have some loose teas in a test tube-like rack on the wall behind the snack display. The Slow Bar even makes the slow dripped tea look like a lab experiment.

I've heard about these guys when they were just a pop-up but was never able to go prior because of my working hours. I got a better job with better hours and the Boba Guys got a brick and mortar, the stars finally aligned for me to try their concoctions! 

So the menu on 6/29/2014
Drinks:
Class Milk Tea: $4
Jasmine Milk Tea: $4
Soy Milk Tea: $4
Horchata Boba: $4
Thai Tea: $4
Iced Matcha Latte: $4
Coffee Milk Tea: $4
Hong Kong Style:  ($4) Black tea with organic condensed milk

Bonus points for having both soy milk and almond milk options!

Milk Tea Slow Bar: Options with or w/out milk. Sweetness level is adjustable. May take up to 5 min
Muscat Oolong: $5.50
Golden Honey Black: $5.50
Lychee Green Tea: $5
Chamomile Mint: $5
Decaf Black: $5
Duke of Earl Grey: $5
Coconut Green Tea: $5

Toppings:
Tapioca Balls
Almond Jelly
Grass Jelly

They also sell snacks like Sugar & Spun cotton candy, liege waffles, macrons, cupcakes, etc. I think it differs all the time though.

My friend and I both ordered the Lychee Green Tea which was part of the Slow Bar. She also bought a Jasmine Milk Tea to bring home for her sister since she was in town for the summer and was craving it. We both thought the milk tea was very light and refreshing (especially since it was so warm and we were walking all over the Mission) so it was worth the slight wait. I've been to other boba places where the wait is even longer, so not bad! 

I typically don't have the tapioca peals in my drinks because so many places does it wrong, but here they're so soft and not overly chewy. So good!

They sold out of their Mason Jar mugs when I went! Bummer. Looks like I'll have an excuse to go back to try again. :D

excerpts: Two Hong Kong style milk teas and one classic milk tea which were all pretty good.
The texture of the Boba was pleasant and chewy.
It is a bit pricey though, especially the Mason jars.
But they have great drinks.
hong kong style.author: Rachel L.
hong kong style.review: I asked the cashier for recommendations and she was so sweet and informative about their specials! Ended up getting the pumpkin Chai which she was right, it is refreshing and quite sweet. Two Hong Kong style milk teas and one classic milk tea which were all pretty good. The texture of the Boba was pleasant and chewy. It is a bit pricey though, especially the Mason jars. But they have great drinks.

excerpts: My go to is usually the Hong Kong style milk tea, but today I decided to get a match green tea latte.
BOMB.
hong kong style.author: Bel W.
hong kong style.review: This is my ultimate favorite boba place. Their boba is bomb and their ingredients are real and fresh. My go to is usually the Hong Kong style milk tea, but today I decided to get a match green tea latte. BOMB. I've also gotten their horchata & Thai tea and they are both flavor filled and delicious!

excerpts: I tried the Hong Kong Style Milktea with boba and grass jelly.
It was pretty good
but it tasted a little watered down.
The boba had a nice bouncy consistency but the grass jelly was a little hard.
The grass jelly didn't have much of a taste to it
and it was hard to slurp up because it was so hard to get into the straw and most of it just sank to the bottom.
I would probably pass on getting the grass jelly topping and just get boba next time.
They do have an interesting selection of boba drinks, but the lines can be long and its always impossible to find a good parking nearby.
hong kong style.author: Lisa H.
hong kong style.review: I tried the Hong Kong Style Milktea with boba and grass jelly. It was pretty good but it tasted a little watered down. The boba had a nice bouncy consistency but the grass jelly was a little hard. The grass jelly didn't have much of a taste to it and it was hard to slurp up because it was so hard to get into the straw and most of it just sank to the bottom. I would probably pass on getting the grass jelly topping and just get boba next time. They do have an interesting selection of boba drinks, but the lines can be long and its always impossible to find a good parking nearby.

excerpts: My friends really liked the Hong Kong style tea that they got though, stating that it was bitter just like they liked it.
hong kong style.author: Sean H.
hong kong style.review:
Boba Guys has been on my bookmarks for what seems like forever now. The opportunity to come here never arose though, since I don't frequent the city much. Finally though, the clouds parted and I was able to discovery what the hoopla is about this place.

Got the Horchata Boba because I figured it was the most unique thing on the menu. Wasn't bad at all. Tastes exactly how it sounds to be honest. My friends really liked the Hong Kong style tea that they got though, stating that it was bitter just like they liked it. 

The store itself is pretty cramped, and there was a pretty decent sized line when we got there, but it all went by pretty quick. The bobarista was pretty chill as well. Friendly and talkative so that's always a big plus. 

Definitely gonna give this place another visit whenever I get the chance to. The Horchata Boba had a lot of promise but I feel like I needa try out one of their slow drips to get that full experience. Will update with results eventually.

excerpts: I had ordered a hong kong style milktea and it wasnt sweet enough
so I brought it back
and they remade one for me.
They also have the best boba.
Their boba is cooked perfectly with it being chewy and soft.
I would recommend classic milk tea, hong kong style, jasmine milk tea, and matcha iced latte.
hong kong style.author: Yushi C.
hong kong style.review:
This is probably my favorite boba place. I drink a lot of tea so when I drink milk tea, I still want to taste the tea. A lot of boba shop disappoint me because of how watery or sugary their drinks are. At boba guys, I believe that they use real tea to make their milk teas. The people working their are also really friendly and will fix your drink if you don't like it. 
I had ordered a hong kong style milktea and it wasnt sweet enough so I brought it back and they remade one for me. They also have the best boba. Their boba is cooked perfectly with it being chewy and soft. 
I would recommend classic milk tea, hong kong style, jasmine milk tea, and matcha iced latte.

excerpts:
A modern lab of supreme boba and everything that is taiwanese, traditional, new and crazy about it

Traditional Taiwanese boba dipped in the traditional brown sugar syrup (customizable to honey syrup), bathed in the hot/cold bath of classical milk tea, Hong Kong style condensed milk tea, or any of the creative blends of green tea, rose, ... real tea leaves with milk... not just any milk Strauss, from a local family ranch.
hong kong style.author: Dilys S.
hong kong style.review:
A modern lab of supreme boba and everything that is taiwanese, traditional, new and crazy about it

Traditional Taiwanese boba dipped in the traditional brown sugar syrup (customizable to honey syrup), bathed in the hot/cold bath of classical milk tea, Hong Kong style condensed milk tea, or any of the creative blends of green tea, rose, ... real tea leaves with milk... not just any milk Strauss, from a local family ranch.

I happened to run into the boba guys, specifically Andrew, who couldn't help but just educate me a bit on boba. I haven't been to Taiwan, but have drunk my fair share from Tea Era, Verde, to the Cha for Tea on UC Irvine campus, but his lecture was a new bell ring for me, so many variations, so much possibility.

They are starting their Kickstarter campaign this week, you can become a sponsor of their new lab, get a black card, or let's say 365 days supply of boba... wow, boba tea on kickstarter? yes the point is these guys are crazy, they are taking boba to a whole other level. 

This is a true challenge for a beverage connoisseur - one may pass by and miss this place, because it is so counter intuitive, its modern design, and glossy feel, reminds you nothing of boba, yet these people are crazy about boba, also cotton candy flavors such as thai tea and black sesame, waffles, and Hong Kong fat toast with melts and soaked in cream. 

It is NOT easy to find your perfect drink here, because everything is customizable, creating a challenge for you to step out of your comfort zone.  Choices can be overwhelming, but having choices is such a blessing. I will slowly try it all. Go try it, too

excerpts: We tried the hong kong style milk tea with boba, classic black with almond jello, and a strawberry tea with boba.
They were all good.
The tea was strong.
The milk was good.
The almond jello was substantial.
The strawberry tea was fresh.
hong kong style.author: claudia y.
hong kong style.review:
when did boba get all fancy and expensive?  We tried the hong kong style milk tea with boba, classic black with almond jello, and a strawberry tea with boba.  They were all good.  The tea was strong.  The milk was good.  The almond jello was substantial.  The strawberry tea was fresh.  Boba chewy.  

Would love to try more things but spending close to $6 for boba is not good for my wallet.

excerpts: like: Classic, Coffee, Thai, Hong Kong Style, Horchata (yum!)
hong kong style.author: Jennifer L.
hong kong style.review:
Gourmet milk teas in the mission district. A simple, no nonsense menu with classic favorites and unique flavors. Everything organic, handcrafted, no syrups, no artificial colors, no powders, no nonsense! With most drinks you can tailor the sweetness and amounts of ice. Drinks start at $3.50, each topping is $0.50.

Visiting from LA and lover of all things milk tea, I had to try this place out. I ordered the Horchata with grass jelly ($4). Although I wasn't able to tailor the sweetness of this pre-mixed drink (I normally order 25% sweetness), this rice milk, cinnamon concoction was right down my alley and wasn't overly sweet. The grass jelly had a semi-grainy texture, but was a refreshing taste that didn't taste artificial. 

- They have classic and unique flavor milk teas ($3.50) like: Classic, Coffee, Thai, Hong Kong Style, Horchata (yum!) Iced Matcha Latte and Jasmine.
- Slow Bar: I was interested in their slow-brewed, heirloom teas, but I was in a rush. Earl Grey, Rose Tea, Lychee Green Tea caught my eye. I'll have to come back.
- Toppings ($0.50 each): Almond Jelly, Grass Jelly, Lychee Jelly, Boba.
- Next time I'd like to try their boba.Ask for a sample of their fun cotton candy flavors. I tried Cookies and Cream and Rice Crispies. I would have bought one if I didn't already hit my sweets limit that day.

Boba Guys, come down to so cal!

excerpts: I ordered Hong Kong style milk tea
and yup that was the best boba milk tea I have ever had!
It wasn't too sweet and the tapioca chewiness was perfect.
I love the interior of the store!
I'm from the East Bay
and I will definitely make the trip again!
hong kong style.author: Samantha M.
hong kong style.review:
So happy i was introduced to this great Boba place. Was able to meet the co founder of Boba guys who was very friendly! 

I ordered Hong Kong style milk tea and yup that was the best boba milk tea I have ever had! It wasn't too sweet and the tapioca chewiness was perfect. I love the interior of the store! I'm from the East Bay and I will definitely make the trip again! They will also have a new location coming up around San Francisco, they also have one in Berkeley that sells Alcoholic boba which I will try one of these days! 

Besides the deliciousness, GO THERE and try it out! Worth the trip.

excerpts: I ordered the Hong Kong Style with grass jelly.
It was good, but since I normally like my drinks sweeter than the average person, I added in some syrup to suit my tastes.
Out of my friends, I finished my drink first (partly because grass jelly is quicker to chew and swallow than boba pearls) because it was that tasty!
Lastly, if I'm ever in the area, I'll make sure to give them a visit and then head over to nearby Dolores Park and enjoy the view.
hong kong style.author: Bunny M.
hong kong style.review:
I like Boba Guys. Sweet and straight to the point. Although the interior is a bit cramped, the line goes pretty quickly! If it's just you and a friend, you can maybe catch seats behind the window. Otherwise, your group is in as soon as it is out.

The menu is what I meant by straight to the point. The milk teas are $3.50 (16 oz) and $4.50 (20 oz) and some you can order hot or cold. I ordered the Hong Kong Style with grass jelly. It was good, but since I normally like my drinks sweeter than the average person, I added in some syrup to suit my tastes. Out of my friends, I finished my drink first (partly because grass jelly is quicker to chew and swallow than boba pearls) because it was that tasty! Lastly, if I'm ever in the area, I'll make sure to give them a visit and then head over to nearby Dolores Park and enjoy the view.

excerpts: My sister and I ordered the cold Hong Kong Style milk tea with no "Toppings" (boba/jelly).
The price was moderate, good service (the two ladies behind the counter were prompt, courteous, and overall friendly), and the service was quick...
The Hong Kong Style milk tea was slightly sweeter than the traditional HK style but still pretty good.
hong kong style.author: Lenerd J.
hong kong style.review:
Came here on a Friday evening-ish and it was surprisingly empty. My sister and I ordered the cold Hong Kong Style milk tea with no "Toppings" (boba/jelly). The price was moderate, good service (the two ladies behind the counter were prompt, courteous, and overall friendly), and the service was quick...although that might be due to the fact that there was only two other customers...

The Hong Kong Style milk tea was slightly sweeter than the traditional HK style but still pretty good. Comes in one size, hot or cold. 

I would definitely come back to try the other drinks on the menu. They serve a few baked goods, for example HK style toast (that might be the wrong name but then again I've no idea what the difference is versus other toast...?), macarons (they were out of these items when we showed up), and a few other things I can't remember.

excerpts: Hong Kong Style Milk Tea was also on point.
hong kong style.author: Yvonne K.
hong kong style.review:
Horchata with boba was goood. Just the right about of sweetness.
Hong Kong Style Milk Tea was also on point.

Liking these two drinks better than the jasmine milk tea I had at their first location that I couldn't taste enough of tea. 

Their cotton candy looked interesting but a little pricey to buy. Looked like they had samples at the register though..

Really glad they have their own little place now. No more trekking over to the Mission only to see that they aren't there.

excerpts: I also ordered a Hong Kong Style Toast with condensed milk, which was 1 thick toast, sliced into 1/4th's, with whipped cream spread and honey or condensed milk drizzled over it.
hong kong style.author: Mandy G.
hong kong style.review:
I normally go to T pumps, ShareTea, or Purple Kow for my boba fix. I am happy to announce that I got out of my comfort zone and finally tried Boba Guys!! 

There are only 2 shops for Boba Guys - Stockton St and 19th St. I came to the one on 19th St because it is not only closer, but I naively thought this was on 19th AVE (lulz). Located in the hipster area of Mission, this storefront is small. Since it is Mission, parking is a bit hard to find due to metered spots. I luckily got a prime parking by the front of the store..but only after circling a bit. 

Small storefront with only a bar-countertop seating by the front window that has only about 3-4 seats, and a bench in front of the windows. They have a good selection of drinks ranging from your typical Green Milk Tea or Jasmine Milk Tea to Horchata Milk Tea, which I thought is quite a unique flavor to add to the menu since it is more of a Mexican drink. Sadly, I didn't order it for my first time. Aside from the menu on the wall, there is a 'special' menu on the side by the cash register on mini-clipboards. The staff was very nice and got our drinks done by the time we finished ordering (whaaa)!! 

I ordered a Strawberry Jasmine Tea-Fresco and my boyfriend (wow, he finally shows up again on my Yelp reviews..been MIA on my adventures..) got the Strawberry-Calpico Tea-Fresco(?). You get to choose your size (16 oz - 24 oz), toppings (tapioca, almond jelly, grass jelly), Milk (Straus Family Organic Milk, Almond Milk, Soy milk), and sweetness level (see chart on wall). 

Strawberry Jasmine Tea-Fresco is good. It's sweet and I feel like you can taste the flavors of the strawberry. My bf ordered the Strawberry-Calpico Tea-Fresco and was a bit disappointed because he felt that it didn't taste like Calpico. I got a sip of his drink and it tasted like my drink, mixed with yogurt - so I guess you can say strawberry yogurt..but in liquid form? Haha. 
I also ordered a Hong Kong Style Toast with condensed milk, which was 1 thick toast, sliced into 1/4th's, with whipped cream spread and honey or condensed milk drizzled over it. Was a bit of a disappointment for me, but slightly met my expectation.. 

Overall, I think I would come back if I was in the area. It's a bit of a drive since I am not in the area often, looking for parking is complicated, and the drinks remind me of T pumps - only difference is that they use organic products and loose-leaf tea instead of powder. Also, I'm sure the lines are long during the day (came at night) and it's just too much of a hipster hype for me :(

excerpts:
Horchata, Hong Kong style, Chamomile Mint, Pumpkin Chai, Muscat Oolong, and Coconut Green Tea.
5.
Not just boba.
They recently started selling snacks too (macarons, toast, etc), but I have yet to try.
They sell cute glass mason jars with handles for $10 with the Boba Guys logo in the front.
If you bring the Boba Guys jar or your own mug, you will receive a discount off your drink!
Grade-A balls
AKA fresh.
Homemade syrup.
They don't use powder or artificial syrup.
Homemade almond and grass jelly.
Slightly hipster and more "Americanized.
The Classic Milk Tea is WAY more sweet compared to the Hong Kong style milk tea.
hong kong style.author: Vicki L.
hong kong style.review:
What makes Boba Guys unique:

1. Limited selection. Only 9 milk tea's. And 8 "Slow Bar" brewed tea's. 
2. Only toppings available are boba and jelly. Very limited.
3. Expensive compared to other places. $4 per drink with no size options.
4. Some unique flavors. Horchata, Hong Kong style, Chamomile Mint, Pumpkin Chai, Muscat Oolong, and Coconut Green Tea.
5. Not just boba. They recently started selling snacks too (macarons, toast, etc), but I have yet to try.
6. They sell cute glass mason jars with handles for $10 with the Boba Guys logo in the front.
7. If you bring the Boba Guys jar or your own mug, you will receive a discount off your drink!
8. Grade-A balls AKA fresh.
9. Homemade syrup. They don't use powder or artificial syrup.
10. Homemade almond and grass jelly.
11. Slightly hipster and more "Americanized." They have some non-Asian staff, which makes this boba shop a little more unique!

Note: The Classic Milk Tea is WAY more sweet compared to the Hong Kong style milk tea.

excerpts: Hong Kong style milk tea was not good.
It was below average.
I've had Hong Kong milk teas from different places and this is probably the worst one I've ever drank.
It was very creamy/milky and barely had any tea taste to it.
And like their menu claims it's suppose to have some bitterness to it, but what I got was straight up milky.
hong kong style.author: Ashley D.
hong kong style.review:
Hong Kong style milk tea was not good. It was below average. I've had Hong Kong milk teas from different places and this is probably the worst one I've ever drank. It was very creamy/milky and barely had any tea taste to it. And like their menu claims it's suppose to have some bitterness to it, but what I got was straight up milky. It tasted like homemade milk tea when I add too much milk or condensed milk. 

However, their jasmine milk tea was good.

excerpts: Got their hong kong style milk tea and taste great!
Great place to stop by after going to brunch at radish nearby!
Fast service!
hong kong style.author: Christopher G.
hong kong style.review: Their drinks are awesome! Got their hong kong style milk tea and taste great! Great place to stop by after going to brunch at radish nearby! Fast service!

excerpts: They are one of few places that actually serves hong kong style milk tea and the only one I know that serves horchata milk tea too.
I tried the hong kong style milk tea, regular milk tea, and the matcha milk tea.
hong kong style.author: Jade L.
hong kong style.review:
The milk tea isn't bad, but it isn't amazing compared to other places out there. I go here when I make a trip to the mission and it is pretty much the only milk tea spot around. They are one of few places that actually serves hong kong style milk tea and the only one I know that serves horchata milk tea too. I tried the hong kong style milk tea, regular milk tea, and the matcha milk tea. I will probably order the matcha drink again...

The only bad thing I can really say about this place is that its really hot. I was sweating waiting for my drink.

excerpts: My favorite drink here is the Hong Kong Style Milk Tea which is a Milk Tea made with Condensed milk.
hong kong style.author: James N.
hong kong style.review:
The drinks here are good if you come on the right day. What really bothers me is their lack of consistency. My first visit, the drinks were amazing. I was so glad that I decided to visit the closer location opposed to going to my usual on Stockton Street.

My favorite drink here is the Hong Kong Style Milk Tea which is a Milk Tea made with Condensed milk. Avoid the Almond Jelly, it's way to overwhelming and ruins the flavor.

On their off days, it taste extremely watered down. On good days, it taste simply amazing.

As soon as they start maintaining their flavors i'll update my review. Till then!

3 Stars.

excerpts: My personal favorite is the Hong Kong Style milk tea, a black milk tea in which they use condensed milk to sweeten the drink.
hong kong style.author: Curtis Y.
hong kong style.review:
Honestly, some of the most genuine tasting milk tea I've had around the city. Their drinks actually come out very sweet most of the time, but if you let the ice melt into the drink, it'll dilute it perfectly so that the drink has the right sweetness. 

My personal favorite is the Hong Kong Style milk tea, a black milk tea in which they use condensed milk to sweeten the drink. I'm a big fan of that, and I'm glad they do that drink justice. 

It's a bit pricier here for drinks, but I think of this place as a treat for myself whenever I feel like I've done a pat-in-the-back worthy task for the day. 

Would recommend to others.

excerpts: Go ahead and try the Rose milk tea and the Hong Kong style ones as well because those are both excellent choices as well.
hong kong style.author: Aaron W.
hong kong style.review:
Okay fine...I'll admit that one of the first reasons for why I wanted to come here a couple years ago was because they put their milk tea in a mason jar. I mean come on, HOW HIPSTER IS THAT?! Yeah there's other boba places that do that now, but Boba Guys was one of the first places that pioneered this mason jar/glass jar boba movement. It makes me sad that now they mainly just use regular cups...but oh well, they had a good run.

This place isn't just about being hipster and glamorous though. The boba and milk tea is actually good! They have a pretty wide variety of options, but I like sticking to the originals. My favorite is the jasmine milk tea, but you can't go wrong with the classic black milk tea. Go ahead and try the Rose milk tea and the Hong Kong style ones as well because those are both excellent choices as well. 

What separates this place from others is the fact that their boba is actually good too. It always seems to be the right balance of chewiness and firmness! Yum. These guys really are the boba guys.

excerpts: I ordered a Hong Kong Style and because condensed milk is already an ingredient, I didnt think I needed to add any sweetness.
I was totally wrong.
The drink was actually undrinkable.
I just confirmed with the worker, you should always choose "100% Sweetness" for it to be the normal sweetness you wouldve gotten if you ordered in their store.
And btw today, it said that Golden Honey Black was sold out on Postmates but when I went in store it is not sold out.
hong kong style.author: Sarina A.
hong kong style.review: FYI, if you use Postmates to order Boba Guys, it automatically defaults to 0% sweetness. I ordered a Hong Kong Style and because condensed milk is already an ingredient, I didnt think I needed to add any sweetness. I was totally wrong. The drink was actually undrinkable. I just confirmed with the worker, you should always choose "100% Sweetness" for it to be the normal sweetness you wouldve gotten if you ordered in their store. And btw today, it said that Golden Honey Black was sold out on Postmates but when I went in store it is not sold out.

excerpts: I've tried the thai iced tea, horchata, hong kong style and matcha green tea as well and they are all just as delicious.
hong kong style.author: Lisa H.
hong kong style.review:
Their jasmine milk tea is honestly the best I've ever had. It's rich in flavor and is always fresh. I've tried the thai iced tea, horchata, hong kong style and matcha green tea as well and they are all just as delicious. The boba is really sweet and has a chewy consistency to it. 

They atmosphere of the place is really great. It's kind of like a hipster tapioca place. The wait to order is never long. I have never waited for more than 5 minutes to order and I usually get my drinks in about 2 or 3 minutes. There is a small seating area too. 

4 stars because of the price for the drink. I understand that the tea is really good quality but 4 dollars seems a little steep. Also, there's only one size for all the drinks. Sometimes I just need a large drink after a rough day. And sometimes the thirst is just real.

excerpts: Hong Kong Style
: This was their best drink out of the lot.
Surprisingly, for such a terrible milk tea place that Americanized the milk tea industry like Tea Pumps, which just means... detroying it.... they managed to get HONG KONG STYLE pretty good.
I tried this one last in the lot...
hong kong style.author: Gregory F.
hong kong style.review:
Gimmick or the real deal? 

It's a gimmick. And it's hype. People are just convincing themselve it's good because of the marketing (that's marketing anyway). I don't know which is worse, Tea Pumps or this place. And if you think Tea Pumps is good, you're not Asian enough or you're too Americanized to know what is "good." (Americanized versions of Asian things are always bad if you've tried the Asian-original, whether it be movies or food) And Tea Pumps and Boba Guys are oviously the PF Changs of Chinese food. "chinese" food.

For a company that markets themselves as meticulous guys scientifically crafting the best milk tea recipes, I'd say these scientists missed the mark pretty hard. I think it was not so much meticulous crafting, but more just a few guys in a kitchen mixing stuff together without the slightest culinary skill or wit whatsover... like college dorm kids that don't know how to cook or mix flavors... because these are by far the worst ratios and recipes I've ever had, aside from Tea Pumps.  

Political news needs to fact-check, BobaGuys needs to flavor-check. But they really need to think about flavors not so much in a scientific process. It's also wit and experience in a culinary sense. Like I said, it's like college dorm kids without the slightest sophistication of taste or the slightest art of cooking trying to play with a bunch of beakers n pans. Mixing flavors and devising combinations is wit and intuition, not calculation and process.

-------------
I came in with a large party and tried several flavors:

Jasmine milk tea: I often jude a milk tea shop by this standard. It's classic, simple, but takes understanding of milk tea to get it PROPERLY made. Well, these guys managed to screw this up. 3 of us ordered it just to be sure. And yes, they all came out identically disgusting.  -- too watery, yet milk to tea ratio... too much milk--so it tasted plain. 75% sweet. 100% sweet. Both pointless It's like adding more sugar to water. The tea was standard jasmine but more importantly, the ratios were all wrong. 

Earl Grey Milk tea: This is my staple order at any milk tea place that would serve it. I've tried it EVERYWHERE. You can say I'm a bit of a harlot for earl grey milk tea... I've been everywhere for it. Well, Boba Guys destroyed this drink. Good job. B for effort. 
It was too watery; had a sharp hint of lychee; had a gross accent of lavender, which I now assume they used the BUTT of all teas--TAZO.. or they used the post 2012 Mighty Leaf version of Earl Grey... which is beyond butt.. and I distinctly remember that nightmare to this day, and I slightly relived it in this milk tea. And the tea to mlik to water ratio was obviously wrong. It just did NOT taste good.

Horchatta Milk tea: not bad. not great. It was like a watery Horchatta with boba. Not so great. They're better off with the store-bought and just throwing boba in it. They don't know how to make horchatta properly.

Hong Kong Style: This was their best drink out of the lot. Surprisingly, for such a terrible milk tea place that Americanized the milk tea industry like Tea Pumps, which just means... detroying it.... they managed to get HONG KONG STYLE pretty good. I tried this one last in the lot... maybe anything par would seem good.

I'm not a fan of Quickly's or TapEx, but there are a few with owners that really know how to make it. But I've also had the worst of the lot, to the point of spitting it back into the cup and chucking it into the trash. And Boba Guys, along with Tea Pumps, are in a tight race for the worst.

excerpts: They have some really awesome flavors like horchata and hong kong style, but all the classics are delicious as well.
hong kong style.author: Sw A.
hong kong style.review:
The bad reviews for this place are due to people complaining about price, long lines, and their branding (come on, really?). 
Boba Guys is wonderful.  They have some really awesome flavors like horchata and hong kong style, but all the classics are delicious as well. I am partial to the jasmine milk tea one - and they always give me the option of choosing what type of milk and level of sweetness. 
The boba itself is soft and chewy - and they give you a generous amount per cup. I can't recommend any other boba place as highly as Boba Guys.

excerpts: But I tried their Hong Kong Style milk tea, but it was so delicious I can't wait to get the chance to go again!
hong kong style.author: Charmaine D.
hong kong style.review: This place looked so hipster, I was a little afraid to walk into this little store.  But I tried their Hong Kong Style milk tea, but it was so delicious I can't wait to get the chance to go again!  Also, they offer free samples of their delicious cotton candy; how cool!

excerpts: I've tried the black milk tea and the hong kong style and they're both sooooo good.
I also really like that they have different options of milk.
I've tried the soy milk and it makes your drink just a tad sweeter.
I would recommend that you try this place!
You can really taste the fresh tea!
The only thing I don't like is that their shop so small!
hong kong style.author: Kelly S.
hong kong style.review: This is by far my favorite boba place. I tried boba guy when they first open a couple of years ago and didn't think much of it. I recently tried their milk tea again and now im obsessed. I've tried the black milk tea and the hong kong style and they're both sooooo good. I also really like that they have different options of milk. I've tried the soy milk and it makes your drink just a tad sweeter. I would recommend that you try this place! You can really taste the fresh tea! The only thing I don't like is that their shop so small!

excerpts: I had the iced matcha latte and the muscat oolong (my favorite), while my friend tried the classic, hong kong style, and lychee green tea (i think she liked the classic best out of those options).
hong kong style.author: Ellen K.
hong kong style.review:
My friend and I came back from SF three weeks ago, and we're still talking about Boba Guys. We had it almost everyday we were there.

Bubbles are the perfect consistency. Almond jelly is sooooo good. 25% sweetened is just enough.

I had the iced matcha latte and the muscat oolong (my favorite), while my friend tried the classic, hong kong style, and lychee green tea (i think she liked the classic best out of those options).

Ugh, now I'm sitting at work craving Boba Guys... :(

excerpts: As for the milk teas, the Hong Kong Style and Horchata tastes amazing.
Overall a better alternative to places like Tpumps.
hong kong style.author: Brian T.
hong kong style.review: Boba guys definitely one of the better tapioca places I've been to. The texture of their boba is soft, chewy, and lightly sweetened. As for the milk teas, the Hong Kong Style and Horchata tastes amazing. Overall a better alternative to places like Tpumps.

excerpts: First time I've seen "hong kong style" milk tea at a boba place before so I had to order it.
The flavor is pretty spot on, but it was sweeter than I would like.
I ordered it with almond jelly and it tasted sooo good.
It was soft and full of flavor.
hong kong style.author: Rosie W.
hong kong style.review:
First time I've seen "hong kong style" milk tea at a boba place before so I had to order it. The flavor is pretty spot on, but it was sweeter than I would like. I ordered it with almond jelly and it tasted sooo good. It was soft and full of flavor. I'll def be back and get it half as sweet.

I purchased the mason mug for $10. Total ripoff but I couldn't resist - its so cute!

excerpts: My friend got the hong kong style milk tea with grass jelly.
While you can't go wrong with black tea and condensed milk, milk to grass jelly proportion was way off.
hong kong style.author: Julia N.
hong kong style.review:
Cute little boba shop in Mission, with funky tea flavors and many options for milk and add-ons. 

I got a Jasmine milk tea (without boba because I'm not that into it) - the tea was good but could be stronger. My friend got the hong kong style milk tea with grass jelly. While you can't go wrong with black tea and condensed milk, milk to grass jelly proportion was way off. He ended up with so much grass jelly after finishing off most of his milk tea.

I'll come for the friendly staff and chill atmosphere, but I didn't think the milk tea was worth the $4 we each paid. Definitely better options out there!

excerpts: I got the Hong Kong style milk tea with pearls.
It's definitely thicker and sweeter than normal PMT.
I like it!
Service is super fast as well.
hong kong style.author: Michael W.
hong kong style.review:
Pricy! But pretty good!

This was my first time in their new location. It's pretty fancy and clean!

I got the Hong Kong style milk tea with pearls. It's definitely thicker and sweeter than normal PMT. I like it! Service is super fast as well. Pearls have the right amount of chewiness and you can really taste the tea.

If I had more time, I would try out the slow bar, as I've heard good things about it.

excerpts: Their menu was very interesting, and had a great range of types of milk tea combinations from classic, Hong Kong style, to horchata.
They also have different add-ins, such as grass jelly and almond jelly, as well as different milk options including almond and soy.
hong kong style.author: Vivian L.
hong kong style.review:
After having been on our list since they opened their old location, we finally got to try this place! We stopped by while waiting for our table at Tacolicious just a block away. Their menu was very interesting, and had a great range of types of milk tea combinations from classic, Hong Kong style, to horchata. They also have different add-ins, such as grass jelly and almond jelly, as well as different milk options including almond and soy. There's also a "slow bar" where they offer hot brewed teas.

We ordered a soy milk tea with boba to share. There was just enough tea flavor and the boba had a good chew to them. The only negative was the syrup on the boba was a little too sweet, but it wasn't a huge deal.

This location is really just a small room that had a small counter with bar stools for about 4-5 people to sit, but there's a bench right outside the store for more seating. It's tucked away in a side street, and can be easily missed.

They also make uniquely-flavored cotton candy, as well as some Asian snacks. They've done a good job with the brand so far. I'm glad they have upgraded to their own storefront and hope they will continue to grow.

excerpts: Love their Hong Kong style milk tea so much!!!
But really hard to find parking there.
hong kong style.author: Harmony Y.
hong kong style.review: Love their Hong Kong style milk tea so much!!! But really hard to find parking there.

excerpts: Hong Kong Style Milk Tea ($4.00):
hong kong style.author: Erica T.
hong kong style.review:
I went here on Sunday (during half time Niners vs. Packers game). They had the chocolate and strawberry boba special that day. 

Hong Kong Style Milk Tea ($4.00): my friend liked it, not a lot of places make milk tea with condense milk so this was a plus. 

Chocolate and strawberry -special ($5.00): Hrm.... this was a weird combination for a milk tea drink, my friend didn't like it, but if you drink if for a while, you kinda get used to it. The tea used was very very light (as if they reused the tea from a previous cup). 

Don't expect these drinks to be flavorful, it is light and refreshing. The tea was very very light. If you are craving an actual boba drink full of creamy richness, don't come here.

excerpts: Hong Kong style, could be better, but tastes like it does in most American places.
Waits are pretty quick for your drink when there's no line, and the prices aren't terrible (in between $3-4).
You'll have to go through hipster land to get here, so buyer beware.
hong kong style.author: Danny C.
hong kong style.review: The first time I came here, the tea quality was pretty bad, and the waits were super long. Because of a friend, I gave them a second chance, and they did impress. Jasmine milk tea, on point. Hong Kong style, could be better, but tastes like it does in most American places. Waits are pretty quick for your drink when there's no line, and the prices aren't terrible (in between $3-4). You'll have to go through hipster land to get here, so buyer beware.

excerpts: They're even pretty fresh with the unique drinks on their small menu such as the Horchata milk tea or the Hong Kong style milk tea.
hong kong style.author: Kristine T.
hong kong style.review:
You know boba is cool if you can find boba in the Mission. It's pretty hip here with the mascot and the simplicity of Pottery Barn decor. They're even pretty fresh with the unique drinks on their small menu such as the Horchata milk tea or the Hong Kong style milk tea. Cheers to the special touches that makes this place a little different than the rest. 

In terms of the flavor of the drink and the quality of the boba, it's a little lack luster. Good for where you really really want some chewy asian goodness (oh hayy) in the Mission and don't feel like heading west for the better drinks and you don't mind shelling $4 for something that could easily be $2.50. Would recommend the flavors that they don't have anywhere else, like horchata, but if you were thinking of getting that milk tea, i think you're better off elsewhere. The almond jelly though is pretty good.

Wouldn't recommend this place as a first, or second choice, but good if you happen to be in the area and want that craving of milk tea and boba to be filled.

excerpts: We ordered the jasmine milk tea and the Hong Kong style milk tea.
The jasmine milk tea lacked any tea flavor and tasted mainly like milk but the  HK style was perfect with added condensed milk for a thicker drink.
hong kong style.author: Robert T.
hong kong style.review:
I was recommended by a friend to try this boba place in the mission. We ordered the jasmine milk tea and the Hong Kong style milk tea. The jasmine milk tea lacked any tea flavor and tasted mainly like milk but the  HK style was perfect with added condensed milk for a thicker drink. 

In general, the milk tea is good. They don't add a lot of ice and they have a decent amount of boba. The pearls are chewy and fresh and all ingredients here are organic!  

Downside is the higher price ($4) for only 16 oz. and there are no large sizes available. 

Definitely recommended if you want boba in the mission. Better than Quickly.

excerpts: It's more like a cold version of a Hong Kong Style Milk Tea at Chinese cafes, but a bit more sweet.
Not really my style and it sure caught me off guard.
I can say that the tapioca pearls were really good.
hong kong style.author: George Z.
hong kong style.review:
The strange mascot at the front of store lead me to believe this was a boutique shop, but another step closer and I found out this place sells one of my favorite drinks, milk tea. The entrance is quite small and only has enough room for a few bar seats near the window which was unforuntely taken by a bunch of yuppies while visited.

At 4 bucks for the average drink, this isn't a place that you can call cheap milk tea, but for a place that seems to still be getting it feet on the Mission/Valencia market, I can't really blame them. It's worth a shot!

If you've ever had milk tea from chain stores around San Francisco like Quickly or Teaway, this taste much different as they use real bitter tea and milk rather than powder. It's more like a cold version of a Hong Kong Style Milk Tea at Chinese cafes, but a bit more sweet. Not really my style and it sure caught me off guard. I can say that the tapioca pearls were really good. Wish they sold them by the bag!

Apparently, they're opening a milk tea lab at Union Square soon and even has a Kickstarter for it. Although I don't think my minimal contribution in terms of my 4 bucks will be even close to denting the amount they need, I'd like to give these guys a shout out because the concept of opening something like this sounds pretty unique. Good luck, Boba Guys!

excerpts: the Hong Kong Style Milk Tea with the almond jelly, and my boyfriend got the horchata with pearls.
Both were wonderful.
This milk tea is the most creamy, delicious tea I have ever had.
It tastes extremely fresh and natural, no hidden sugars or powders.
The only thing I would change is ask for less ice next time.
The almond jelly was super light flavored, not overpowering of the tea, and was delicious as well.
If you are a fan of boba, you will not regret trying this place!
hong kong style.author: Rachel O.
hong kong style.review:
Boba guys is incredible!!  
I have been drinking milk tea for years from a variety of places, but this one is by far the best!  Fifteen minutes after it opened, the line was already out the door, but it moves fast.
I got the Hong Kong Style Milk Tea with the almond jelly, and my boyfriend got the horchata with pearls.  Both were wonderful.
This milk tea is the most creamy, delicious tea I have ever had.  It tastes extremely fresh and natural, no hidden sugars or powders.  The only thing I would change is ask for less ice next time.
The almond jelly was super light flavored, not overpowering of the tea, and was delicious as well.
If you are a fan of boba, you will not regret trying this place!

excerpts: The Hong Kong Style and Thai Tea were wonderful - refreshing and smooth.
The staff were also really sweet and our drinks arrived quickly.
Definitely hit the mark!
Was happy to stumble upon their store front on this hot day.
Will be back if I'm in the neighborhood
hong kong style.author: Laura C.
hong kong style.review: The Hong Kong Style and Thai Tea were wonderful - refreshing and smooth. The staff were also really sweet and our drinks arrived quickly. Definitely hit the mark! Was happy to stumble upon their store front on this hot day. Will be back if I'm in the neighborhood

excerpts: I was never blown away by most of their drinks in what I would call the regular menu (Hong Kong style, Jasmine Milk Tea, Horchata etc.)
but I finally found THE drink for me here.
For $5, depending on what size, the Mango Matcha Tea Fresca gets an A++
(You'll find this in the menu near the register).
It's made with a fruit puree
so it's a bit thicker than the tea drinks.
Kudos to the staff member who recommended it to me!
You got good taste.
hong kong style.author: Kristine N.
hong kong style.review: I was never blown away by most of their drinks in what I would call the regular menu (Hong Kong style, Jasmine Milk Tea, Horchata etc.) but I finally found THE drink for me here. For $5, depending on what size, the Mango Matcha Tea Fresca gets an A++ (You'll find this in the menu near the register). It's made with a fruit puree so it's a bit thicker than the tea drinks. Kudos to the staff member who recommended it to me! You got good taste.

excerpts: The Hong Kong style was alright
I've had better milk teas elsewhere.
hong kong style.author: Van H.
hong kong style.review: Strawberry Matcha green tea latte was as delicious as it was beautiful. The Hong Kong style was alright I've had better milk teas elsewhere.

excerpts: Next time I am ordering from Boba Guys, I shall try the Hong Kong Style milk tea - hopefully it will be better than my precious experience!
hong kong style.author: Hurnan V.
hong kong style.review:
I came here one afternoon to satisfy my boba cravings while in the Mission. The service staff was extremely friendly and expedient with making my drink. I ordered the jasmine milk tea with boba, and was slightly disappointed. The beverage itself tasted watered down - hardly any tea component and more "milk". The tapioca pearls were also of a strange consistency - a bit too soft around the curves and not as chewy as one would have hoped. Next time I am ordering from Boba Guys, I shall try the Hong Kong Style milk tea - hopefully it will be better than my precious experience!

Other notes--
Pros: all organic! :)
Cons: pretty pricey for the size available ($4 for regular 16oz)

excerpts: Their almond jelly is also good in the Hong Kong style milk tea!
hong kong style.author: Waanmathi V.
hong kong style.review: I love that they don't charge extra for almond milk. Their almond jelly is also good in the Hong Kong style milk tea!

excerpts: I decided to try out the iced matcha latte and my boyfriend tried the hong kong style.
I loved both drinks.

The boba balls were not too soft and chewy, the price was very typical in comparison to other boba places (that's if you don't purchase the mason jar), the service was on the longer side to most boba places i've been to, and finding parking can be tough.
I would most likely come back, but hopefully when its not so busy!
hong kong style.author: Charlene B.
hong kong style.review: So, where I live there aren't many boba places AT ALL (and if there are, the quality is as cheap as the prices they sell for). My boyfriend came to Boba Guys on President's Day (a Monday), and we were enough to find prime time parking along the street right across the shop. When we arrived (around 230pm) there was a bit of a line. It took about 15 minutes to actually reach the inside, which was small and a bit cramped (like most boba places). The register had a display just the to the left of it which showed their signature mason jars and some treats they were selling (sugar spun cotton candy!). I decided to try out the iced matcha latte and my boyfriend tried the hong kong style. I loved both drinks. The boba balls were not too soft and chewy, the price was very typical in comparison to other boba places (that's if you don't purchase the mason jar), the service was on the longer side to most boba places i've been to, and finding parking can be tough. I would most likely come back, but hopefully when its not so busy!

excerpts: I've also tried their thai iced tea, as well as their hong kong style, which were both a bit too sweet (although I could have asked them to tone it down).
I would suggest sticking with their boba, which has a great consistency, and is quite sweet, mostly because I'm not the biggest fan of jellies.
Also, try substituting in almond milk for the regular milk!
It adds nice body and flavor :)
hong kong style.author: Courtney N.
hong kong style.review:
Such a wonderful boba shop! My friends and I joke that it's the most artisan our boba gets, and it's not that much more expensive than the boba shops closer to home.

What I particularly love about this shop is that it doesn't have too many options. Most boba places have a gazillion options, and for indecisive people like me, I spend forever deciding what I want. Having fewer options makes me trust that their options were all carefully crafted/tested and are of high quality, which has been true so far! 

They even brew your tea right when you order, so it's fresh! The teas have a beautiful flavor, particularly the muscat oolong (you can really taste the muscat). I also appreciate that they have so many different options for milk (including almond and soy milk), and that they use healthy, organic products :)

My favorite so far has been the horchata with boba, which always has a delicious amount of spice and flavor. I've also tried their thai iced tea, as well as their hong kong style, which were both a bit too sweet (although I could have asked them to tone it down). I would suggest sticking with their boba, which has a great consistency, and is quite sweet, mostly because I'm not the biggest fan of jellies. Also, try substituting in almond milk for the regular milk! It adds nice body and flavor :)

excerpts: Got the Hong Kong style.
It was great.
hong kong style.author: Benj M.
hong kong style.review: Really great bobas. Pretty sure they make them on site every morning. Got the Hong Kong style. It was great.

excerpts: But omg, their Hong Kong Style Milk Tea, so yummy!
Maybe it's cause they use condensed milk.
MMM!!!
The only thing is they don't have many flavors, but who needs a million flavors anyway?
hong kong style.author: Lina C.
hong kong style.review: I usually don't crave milk tea from anywhere specific because it all tastes generally the same to me. But omg, their Hong Kong Style Milk Tea, so yummy! Maybe it's cause they use condensed milk. MMM!!! The only thing is they don't have many flavors, but who needs a million flavors anyway?

excerpts: They have variety of interesting flavors that I was surprised to see and would definitely like to try when i come back: horchata, decaf, hong kong style, coconut green tea, chamomile mint, muscat oolong, etc.
You can also order online and choose a pick up time!
How convenient!
The place is pretty small, with some window seating, so it's primarily a to-go place.
There is also a bench right outside as well.
I would definitely come back!
I'm excited to hear that they're going to open a store in Union Square, closer to where I live!
I'm sure they'll get a lot of business.
hong kong style.author: Anna L.
hong kong style.review:
I tried the Soy Milk Tea with grass jelly and I really like the strong tea flavor! I felt like it was the right sweetness for me, so there was no reason to adjust the sugar percentage which I realized later I could have done. I thought the grass jelly was okay..I felt like it had a weird texture - more firm and dense than the regular grass jelly that I'm used to. 
I came at a good time when there were not too many people..around 3 something..so I got my drink in like 2 minutes. I like that they have a little station for water with cups and also a jug where you could add extra syrup! According to their website, the syrup, almond jelly, and grass jelly are homemade! I appreciate that they strive to use the best possible ingredients (organic tea and organic condensed milk!) and the best possible milk-tea-making methods to produce good quality drinks. They have variety of interesting flavors that I was surprised to see and would definitely like to try when i come back: horchata, decaf, hong kong style, coconut green tea, chamomile mint, muscat oolong, etc. You can also order online and choose a pick up time! How convenient! 
The place is pretty small, with some window seating, so it's primarily a to-go place. There is also a bench right outside as well.
I would definitely come back! I'm excited to hear that they're going to open a store in Union Square, closer to where I live! I'm sure they'll get a lot of business.

excerpts: Hong Kong style bubble tea!
This is a great little bubble tea shop in Mission that offers oganic bubble tea with either almond jelly or the traditional tapioca ball versions.
The HK style one is nice because its not cloyingly sweet and has a good milky flavor from the organic condensed milk.
hong kong style.author: Alex R.
hong kong style.review: Hong Kong style bubble tea!  This is a great little bubble tea shop in Mission that offers oganic bubble tea with either almond jelly or the traditional tapioca ball versions.  The HK style one is nice because its not cloyingly sweet and has a good milky flavor from the organic condensed milk.

excerpts: Iced matcha latte and Hong Kong style milk tea are definitely worth trying.
Ask for extra ice because it is not cold enough when you get it.
But when the ice settles, it tastes really good.
It's a little on the pricey side and the location is really random..
Boba in the mission district?
Definitely a hipster boba spot
but it is really good.
Service is alright, nothing to rave about.
They also sell macarons but every time I come, they're already sold out.
hong kong style.author: Brenda K.
hong kong style.review: Iced matcha latte and Hong Kong style milk tea are definitely worth trying. Ask for extra ice because it is not cold enough when you get it. But when the ice settles, it tastes really good. It's a little on the pricey side and the location is really random.. Boba in the mission district? Definitely a hipster boba spot but it is really good. Service is alright, nothing to rave about. They also sell macarons but every time I come, they're already sold out.

excerpts: I tried the Hong Kong style milk tea with grass jelly here.
Not too as good as I expected.
The line was outside the store, but the wait wasn't too long.
Maybe I will try something different next time.
hong kong style.author: Suki W.
hong kong style.review: I tried the Hong Kong style milk tea with grass jelly here. Not too as good as I expected.  The line was outside the store, but the wait wasn't too long. Maybe I will try something different next time.

excerpts: When I stop by BG, my go to drink is the Hong Kong style with almond jelly.
They usually make it to my liking but this time was BLAH.
This time it tasted very bland and as if the gal forgot to put in the condensed milk.
Also, it had a bitter aftertaste.
Disappointed.
hong kong style.author: Kim N.
hong kong style.review: When I stop by BG, my go to drink is the Hong Kong style with almond jelly. They usually make it to my liking but this time was BLAH. This time it tasted very bland and as if the gal forgot to put in the condensed milk. Also, it had a bitter aftertaste. Disappointed.

excerpts: Hong Kong style Boba tea was good.
Boba was soft and added a nice flavor.
Drink could've been a tad sweeter, but pretty good nonetheless.
Fun and friendly staff.
hong kong style.author: Sunny J.
hong kong style.review: Hong Kong style Boba tea was good.  Boba was soft and added a nice flavor.  Drink could've been a tad sweeter, but pretty good nonetheless.  Fun and friendly staff.

excerpts: both $4- are hong kong style milk tea with almond jelly & classic milk tea with boba.
They were both good quality & tasting.
The classic tastes different from the usual milk tea & is less sweet than the hong kong one.
Both my boyfriend & I like the classic better.
They gave a lot of jelly though.
hong kong style.author: Angelica L.
hong kong style.review: Limited choices. the 2 drinks I tried- both $4- are hong kong style milk tea with almond jelly & classic milk tea with boba. They were both good quality & tasting. The classic tastes different from the usual milk tea & is less sweet than the hong kong one. Both my boyfriend & I like the classic better. They gave a lot of jelly though.

excerpts: I got the Hong Kong style milk tea expecting it to be sweet and creamy with condensed milk--
it wasn't.
It was very watery and thin.
The tapioca itself is average-- good flavor, average texture; not as soft as Tpumps's honey boba.
Also, my drink didn't even come in a mason jar!
Disappointment all around.
hong kong style.author: Malia B.
hong kong style.review:
Went here today after seeing friends' photos of milk tea and boba in Mason jars and thought, "How hipster!" I knew coming in that the price was high ($4 compared to Teaway Express's $1.07) but I thought it would be worth it. It really wasn't. I got the Hong Kong style milk tea expecting it to be sweet and creamy with condensed milk-- it wasn't. It was very watery and thin. The tapioca itself is average-- good flavor, average texture; not as soft as Tpumps's honey boba. Also, my drink didn't even come in a mason jar! Disappointment all around. I didn't really like my boyfriend's iced matcha latte. 
Honestly I love the attitude and lifestyle of the neighborhood, especially since I live nearby. However it really irked me and my elitist view of being Asian and knowing boba when people come in here not knowing a thing about tapioca. But that's just my own personal tick. 
The one saving grace so far was the green tea cotton candy. It was a little shocking at first, strong, slightly salty matcha with sweet sugar, but it was soon addicting.
